In Aslacton, that town in England --
An ancient stone church stands amid the fields, the sound of bells cascading from the tower of this rural England icon, calling the faithful to evensong, making it one of the loveliest scenes.
The parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels stop to chat at the church's door, as they always have.
In the tower, they pull rhythmically on ropes attached to the bells that were first sounded here in 1614.
But there is also a discordant, modern note in this village, though it can not be heard by those church-goers enjoying the peal of bells this cool autumn evening.
Like most of the other 6,000 churches in Britain with sets of bells, St. Michael's once had their own 'band' of ringers, who would herald every Sunday morning and evening service.
Now, only one local ringer remains: him, 64-year-old Derek Hammond.
Those here today live elsewhere.

A group of 15 ringers, including two octogenarians and four in training, drives every Sunday from church to church in a sometimes-exhausting effort to keep the bells sounding in the many belfries of East Anglia.
To ring for even one service at the bell tower, one has to scrape, says Mr. Hammond, a retired worker from the water authority.
We've tried to train these youngsters, but these discos and dances have them, and they just drift away.
Mr. Hammond worries that old age and the flightiness of youth will diminish the ranks of the group from East Anglia, which keeps the Aslacton bells pealing.
After all, his side is not favored by History.
A nationwide survey from a year ago revealed that nearly a third of the church bells in England, including those in this region, are no longer rung on Sundays due to a lack of people to ring them.
It is easy to see why this ancient art is on the ropes.
The English consider the less complicated version of playing tunes on bells, as done by the carillons of continental Europe, to be childish, fit only for them.
A mind-boggling exercise that the English invented 380 years ago, change-ringing requires physical dexterity -- some bells weigh more than a ton -- along with intense mental concentration.
In larger churches, they start the proper English bells in 'rounds,' beginning with the highest-pitched bell and descending to the lowest, creating a simple scale using as many as 12 bells.
Then, at that signal, they begin varying the order in which these bells sound without altering the steady rhythm of their striking.
The rules state that each change or variation can occur only once.
Ringers memorize patterns of changes, which are known as methods with odd-sounding names such as Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Caters.
A `` peal `` consists of about 5,000 changes and takes them about three hours to complete.
A look at the Thursday night practice at St. Mary Abbot, located in London's Kensington district, gives an idea of the work they involve.

Ten shirt-sleeved ringers stand in this circle, one foot ahead of the other in a prize-fighter's stance, each pulling the rope that disappears through that small hole in the high ceiling of the ringing chamber.
Totally absorbed, the ringers stare straight ahead, using what they call 'rope-sight' to monitor these other ropes and thus synchronize their pulls.
Far above in the belfry, these huge bronze bells, mounted on wheels, swing madly through a full 360 degrees, starting and ending, surprisingly, in the inverted, or mouth-up position.
Skilled ringers use their wrists to advance or retard the next swing, so that it can swap places with another bell in the following change.

Dorothy L. Sayers, the English novelist, described a passion in her well-known detective story involving church bells as one that finds its satisfaction in mathematical completeness and mechanical perfection.
Ringers, she added, are those filled with the solemn intoxication that this intricate ritual faultlessly performed brings.
Stephanie Pattenden, master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of England's best female ringers, admits that ringing does become a bit of an obsession.
That passion usually stays in the tower, however.
More often than not, the ringers consider the belfry as if the church were an object lodged at its base.
When the ringers' changes are completed, and after they have worked up a sweat, they often skip off to the local pub, leaving the worship for others below.
Some clerics do not find this sitting well.
With the Church of England's membership steadily dwindling, these strong-willed vicars are pressing them, often non-religious ringers, to attend services.

Two years ago, Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone, the vicar of Great Torrington, Devon, got so fed up with those ringers who did not attend the service that he sacked them; they promptly set up a picket line in protest.
The Vicar Hummerstone says they were a self-perpetuating club that treated that tower as sort of a separate premises.
An entirely new band, which includes several members of the congregation, will perform today at Great Torrington.
But there still are not enough ringers to ring more than six of those eight bells.
Following a dust-up over St. Mary's Church attendance in Ilminster, Somerset, the church's bells have fallen silent.
But the vicar of a nearby church, C.J.B. Marshall, feels that the fault is in the stairs located next to the altar, which are from the bell tower.
So crunch, crunch, crunch, bang, bang, bang -- here come those from above, making a very obvious exit while they are at prayer, he says.
Vicar Marshall admits to mixed feelings about the issue, since Marshall is both a vicar and an active bell-ringer himself.
The sound of these bells is a net to draw them into the church, he says.
I live in hopes that those ringers will be drawn into a fuller life themselves.
John C. Baldwin, the president, says that a sort of parliament of ringing groups, such as the Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, aims to improve relations with vicars.
The vicar hopes to speak to students at theological colleges about the joys of bell ringing and will shortly publish a booklet for every vicar in the country entitled, 'The Bells in Their Care.'
Mr. Baldwin says, `` They recognize that the church may no longer be as high a priority in their life and experience.``
The greater problem Mr. Baldwin is also attacking is the lack of ringers.
One survey says that of the 100,000 trained bellringers in England today, only 40,000 still remain active.
Also, the bells in small, rural parishes and inner-city churches do not always have ringers living where they need to be rung.
But the program initiated by the council to attract and train ringers is only partly successful, Mr. Baldwin says.
Right now, if we're lucky, we can keep that one new ringer out of 10 after five years, he adds.
A bright sign is the fact that a growing number of them have entered the once male-dominated field; more than a third of the ringers today are these women.
It is not accepted everywhere, however.

The Ancient Society of College Youths, the oldest bell-ringing group in the country, founded in 1637, remains male-only, a fact that is especially frustrating to women since they are the only providers of ringers for the most prestigious churches in Britain, including St. Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey.

Britain has not seen a woman file an equal-opportunity suit, yet the magnitude of the problem became apparent this summer through a series of letters in The Ringing World, a weekly publication for them.

The writer, signing the letter as 'Red-blooded, balanced male,' remarked on the 'frequency of women fainting in peals,' and suggested that women 'settle back into their traditional role of making tea at meetings.'

In the torrent of replies that followed, the woman from Solihull observed that the average male ringer leaves quite a lot to be desired: he is badly dressed, decorated with acne and a large beer-belly, frequently unwashed, and unbearably flatulent in peals.
Sheffield's other woman wrote to say that in her 60 years of ringing, she had never known a lady to faint in the belfry.
I have seen one or two of them die, bless them.

The discovery of these genes by scientists in recent months is painting a new and startling picture of cancer's development.
An emerging understanding of these genes is expected to produce an array of new strategies for future cancer treatment and prevention.
The future is for that.
Already, scientists are developing tests based on these newly identified genes that, for the first time, can predict whether someone who is otherwise healthy is likely to get cancer.
A super-exciting set of discoveries, says Bert Vogelstein, the Johns Hopkins University researcher who has just found a gene pivotal to the triggering of colon cancer.
Only a decade ago, the disease known as cancer was a black box; at the molecular level, we knew nothing about it.
Today, we know that the accumulation of several of those altered genes can initiate cancer and, then, propel it into a deadly state.
Scientists refer to the class of genes known as tumor-suppressors, or they simply label them as anti-cancer genes.
When functioning normally, proteins made by them hold a cell's growth in check.

But if these genes are damaged -- perhaps by radiation, a chemical, or through an accidental event during cell division -- the proteins that normally suppress growth no longer function, and cells that are typically under control can turn malignant.
A family of genes discovered in the early 1980s, called oncogenes, differs from the newly identified ones.
Oncogenes must be present for a cell to become malignant, but researchers have found these in normal as well as cancerous cells, suggesting that these do not cause cancer by themselves.

In recent months, researchers have come to believe these two types of cancer genes work in concert: An oncogene may turn proliferating cells malignant only after that tumor-suppressor gene has been damaged.
Tumor-suppressor genes, like all genes, are inherited in pairs, with one copy from each parent.
Either this copy or that copy can make the proteins needed to control cell growth, so for cancer to arise, both of them must be impaired.

A person who is born with one defective copy of a suppressor gene, or whose one copy is damaged early in life, is especially prone to cancer because they need only lose the other copy for cancer to develop.
Some scientists believe that emerging genetic tests will be able to identify these cancer-susceptible individuals, heralding a new age of predictive cancer diagnosis.
The first beneficiaries of the new findings include Bill and Bonnie Quinlan.
Mr. Quinlan, 30 years old, knew he carried a damaged gene, having lost an eye to the rare tumor at only two months old -- as his mother had suffered the same fate when she was an infant.
Because of the isolation of the retinoblastoma tumor-suppressor gene, the possibility emerged last January to discover the threat that the baby faced.

A test using new 'genetic probes' showed that Will Quinlan had not inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene; hence, he faced no more risk than these other children of developing the rare cancer.
Mr. Quinlan says, "It made the New Year for us."
The first test to predict reliably whether someone could expect to develop cancer was this one.

Equally important, the initial discovery of this gene that controls retinal cell growth, made by Thaddeus Dryja, a Boston doctor, has opened a field of cancer study, which in recent months has exploded.
Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute, says that studying this tragic but uncommon tumor made possible some fundamental insights into the most basic workings of cancer.
All of it may not be obvious to the public, which is concerned about advances in treatment, but I am convinced that this basic research will soon begin showing results there.
To date, scientists have identified two of those cancer-suppressing genes.
Dr. Dryja made the retinoblastoma discovery in 1986.
Then last spring, researchers reported finding a gene, which they called p53, that, if impaired, turns healthy colon cells cancerous.
Soon after this report, two additional research teams found evidence indicating that the same p53 gene is damaged and present in tissue from lung and breast cancers.
These forms of the disease, including colon, lung, and breast cancers, are the most common and lethal, collectively killing almost 200,000 Americans each year.
About a dozen laboratories in the U.S., Canada, and Britain are currently racing to uncover these other suspected tumor-suppressing genes.
About seven candidates are being considered by them.

Researchers say that the inactivation of these tumor-suppressor genes, whether alone or in combination, seems crucial for the development of cancers such as those affecting the brain, skin, kidney, prostate, and cervix.

There is evidence that if individuals inherit defective versions of genes like these, they are especially prone to cancer, perhaps explaining, finally, why some forms of cancer seem to haunt certain family lines.
Alfred G. Knudson Jr., a pediatrician, proposed in the 1970s that retinoblastoma stemmed from two separate genetic defects, which is a significant part of the story of tumor-suppressor genes.
He theorized that in this eye cancer, the infant inherited that damaged copy of the gene from their one parent and a normal copy from the other.
The tumor, he suggested, developed when that second, normal copy was also damaged.
But there was no way to prove the `` two-hit `` theory of Dr. Knudson.
Back then, scientists had no way of ferreting out these specific genes, but under a microscope they could see the 23 pairs of chromosomes in the cells that contain them.
Occasionally, the gross damage to chromosomes was visible.
Dr. Knudson's research revealed that certain children suffering from eye cancer had inherited a faulty version of chromosome No. 13 from a parent affected by the disease.
Under the microscope, he could actually see that a part of chromosome 13 was missing.
He assumed that the gene or genes contained within the missing piece had a critical role in triggering the cancer.
But he did not know that gene or those genes had disappeared.
Then, the scientific team led by Dr. Webster Cavenee, who was then at the University of Utah, found the answer.
The team used these newly developed gene probes, snippets of genetic material that can track the presence of a gene in a cell.
By analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors, researchers found defects in the second copy of chromosome 13 in the exact area as that in the first copy.
The medicine was captivated by the finding.
The first time anyone demonstrated was when they showed that losing both copies of this same gene could result in the onset of cancer.
Dr. Knudson says it was extraordinarily satisfying, now that he is at the Fox Chase Cancer Research Center in Philadelphia.
I was convinced that what was true of retinoblastoma would be true for these cancers.
The claim was audacious.

But in Baltimore, Dr. Vogelstein, a young molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School, believed that he was right, and set out to repeat the experiment of Dr. Cavenee in cells from other cancers.
One of the two research teams, led by him, reported dual chromosome losses in a rare childhood cancer of the kidney known as Wilm's tumor in 1984.
Dr. Vogelstein next turned his attention to this disease, colon cancer, which is the second biggest cancer killer in the U.S. after lung cancer.
He believed that colon cancer might also arise from multiple hits on cancer suppressor genes, because this often seems to develop in stages.

The development of polyps in the bowel often precedes it, which in some cases become increasingly malignant in identifiable stages -- progressing from less severe to deadly -- as though a cascade of genetic damage might be occurring.
Dr. Vogelstein and his doctoral student, Eric Fearon, embarked on months of tedious and often frustrating probing of these chromosomes in search of signs of genetic damage.
A confusing variety of genetic deletions began being uncovered, with some found only in benign polyps, others in malignant cells, and many in both types of polyps and cells.
Gradually, a coherent picture of how that cancer developed emerged.
If that certain gene's both copies were knocked out, benign polyps would develop.
If the second gene's both copies were subsequently deleted, these polyps would progress to malignancy.
It was clear that for colon cancer to develop, more than one gene, such as these, had to be damaged.
The report by them galvanized other molecular biologists.
It was the confirming evidence they all needed that losses of this gene were critical to the development of that common tumor, says Ray White at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City.
But the gene that Dr. Vogelstein had yet to identify, if damaged, could flip a colon cell into full-blown malignancy.
Chromosome 17 was their focus.
For months the researchers from Johns Hopkins, using gene probes, experimentally crawled down the length of it, looking for the smallest common bit of genetic material lost in all tumor cells.
This piece of DNA would probably constitute a gene.
When Dr. Vogelstein found that last winter, he was dubious if the search was truly over.

Arnold Levine, a Princeton University researcher, had discovered several years earlier in experiments with mice that a gene called p53 could transform normal cells into cancerous ones, which stemmed from his doubts about the fact.
Dr. Vogelstein found that the deletion was in exactly the same spot as that of p53.
But Mr. Levine had said that the p53 gene caused cancer by promoting growth, whereas they at Johns Hopkins were looking for a gene that suppressed it.

Despite that, when the Johns Hopkins scientists compared the gene they had found in human cancer cells with Mr. Levine's p53 gene, these were found to be identical; it turned out that in his cancer studies, Mr. Levine had unknowingly been observing a damaged form of p53 -- a cancer-suppressing gene.
Robert Weinberg, a leader in cancer-gene research at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass, says, `` The discovery suddenly puts that obscure gene right in the cockpit of cancer formation. ``
Evidence now is emerging that this p53 suppressor gene is involved not only in breast cancer but in other cancers as well.
Researchers in Edinburgh, Scotland, have found that in 23 of the 38 breast tumors, chromosome 17's one copy was mutated at the location of the p53 gene.
The scientists say that since breast cancer often strikes multiple members of those certain families, the gene, when inherited in that damaged form, may predispose they to the cancer.
It has just been implicated that the p53 gene is involved in lung cancer.
In a report out last week, John Minna and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute say that about half the cells taken from lung cancer tissue they tested are missing the gene.
There also are reports from various labs, as yet unpublished, concerning the absence of p53 genes in tissue samples from these cancers, including kidney, brain, and skin.
At the same time, the team from Johns Hopkins and they are rushing to pinpoint these tumor-suppressor genes.
Dr. Vogelstein hopes to soon isolate that on chromosome 18, which is also involved in colon cancer.
A researcher in Great Britain, Walter Bodmer, and Ray White in Utah are close to finding a gene, involved with some types of colon cancer, thought to be on chromosome 5.
Dr. Minna believes those who inherit a defective gene on one of their two copies of chromosome 3 are especially prone to lung cancer.
Recently, they reported that the retinoblastoma suppressor gene may also be involved in some lung cancers, as well as in several other more common types of cancer, too.
Where they will lead, scientists can only speculate about these discoveries.

Already, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.'s Squibb unit and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. are collaborating with gene hunters to transform the expected cascade of discoveries into predictive tests and, perhaps, new therapies.
Some researchers say new cancer drugs to slow or reverse tumor growth may be based on these suppressor proteins, normally produced by the genes.
The plan would be to administer growth-controlling proteins, which healthy versions of the damaged genes produce, to patients.
It may even be possible to replace these defective genes with healthy versions, though no one has come close to doing so far.
In any case, Dr. Minna of the National Cancer Institute says, `` We're witnessing the discovery of one of these most important steps in the genesis of cancer.

The rout of a GOP congressional hopeful in a Mississippi district that hasn't backed a Democratic presidential candidate since Adlai Stevenson, which occurred on Tuesday, serves as another reminder that, at least at the federal level, the practice of political 'ticket splitting' has been increasing over the past half century.

In the presidential election year of 1948, more than 20% of the nation's congressional districts selected a candidate from a different party for the White House than they did for the House of Representatives.
Now that figure routinely equals a third, and it has been above 40% twice.
As we know, voters tend to favor Republicans more in races for the presidency than they do in those for Congress.

In every presidential election over the past half century, except for Goldwater's presidential candidacy, the GOP has captured a greater percentage of the major-party popular vote for president than it has for congressional seats or the popular vote for Congress.
Prior to 1932, it was nearly the opposite of this pattern.
The results of recent decades are accounted for by what?
A simple economic theory may at least partially explain the split personality this displays among Americans in the voting booth.
Three assumptions support this theory:

Voters can 'buy' one of two brands when they select their political agents -- the Republican brand that believes in the minimalist state and in the virtues of private markets over those of public action, and the Democratic brand that believes in big government and in public intervention to remedy the excesses attendant to the pursuit of private interest.

Congressional representatives have two basic responsibilities: dealing with national issues, such as casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes costs and/or confers benefits on the population at large, and attending to local issues like constituency service and pork barrel.
Republican congressional representatives, because of their belief in a minimalist state, are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than these Democratic members of Congress.
If those assumptions hold, the voters in Congressional races face what economic theory labels a prisoner's dilemma and have an incentive, on the margin, to lean towards the Democratic party.

If a Republican is put into office, not only will the party acquire less in terms of local benefits, but the chosen legislator will be relatively powerless to prevent other legislators from 'bringing home the bacon' to their respective constituencies.
After all, each legislator is just one of these 535 individuals when it comes to making national policy.
In the races for that political seat, the incentive for voters, at the margin, is to favor the Republicans.

Although a GOP president may limit local benefits to the particular district/state of the voter, such a president is also likely to be more effective at preventing other districts/states and their legislators from doing the same.
The standing of that individual voter will consequently be enhanced by lower taxes.
While the theory is exceedingly simple, it appears to explain several phenomena.

First, why the increase and peculiar pattern of ticket splitting over the past half century has occurred: Before Franklin Roosevelt's presidency and the New Deal's advent, the government played a much smaller role in society, and the prisoner's dilemma problem that voters faced in Congressional races was considerably less severe.

Second, it explains why voters hold Congress in disdain but generally love their own representatives: These constituents appreciate the specific benefits their legislator wins for them but not the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing likewise for his constituency.
Third, the theory suggests that those legislators who focus excessively on national policy, as opposed to seeking local benefits, have lower security in their offices.
For example, these first-term members of the House, once the most vulnerable incumbents, have virtually become immune to defeat.

The defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans, which were brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution, was the one exception to this recent trend when they were running for re-election in 1982.
Because these freshmen placed far more emphasis on their partisan role -- spreading the Reagan revolution -- in national policy making, these freshmen were more vulnerable to defeat.
Fourth, the theory indicates why Republicans may have a difficult time attracting viable candidates for congressional office.
Potential candidates may be discouraged from running less by the prospect of defeat at the hands of a Democratic opponent than by the congressional salary.

To the extent that the Republican Party and its financial backers realize the congressional prisoner's dilemma game works to their disadvantage, its attempts to field a competitive slate of candidates will be hindered.
Fifth, this theory may at least partially explain why ticket splitting has been especially prevalent in the southern regions.

To the extent that Southern Democratic legislators have held a disproportionate share of power in Congress since 1932 and have been able to translate this clout into more local benefits for their constituencies, voters in the South have had an especially strong incentive to keep these Democrats in office.
Finally, the theory suggests why they generally have fared better in Senate races than in campaigns for the House.

Since local benefit-seeking matters more and national policy making matters less in the lower chamber of Congress, this pattern is precisely what one would expect when Republicans are less willing to engage in such activities than their Democratic counterparts.
Is there any empirical support for the theory?
The key assumption that Democratic legislators are more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than Republican colleagues is corroborated by three pieces of evidence.
James Bennett and Thomas DiLorenzo, the economists, find that GOP senators turn back roughly 10% more of their allocated personal staff budgets than these Democrats do.

To the extent that the primary duty of a congressman's personal staff involves seeking local benefits, it indicates that their political philosophy leads Republicans in Congress to pay less attention to the specific concerns of their constituents.

Second, if this key assumption is valid, Democrats should have lower attendance rates on roll-call votes than those of Republicans to the extent that such votes reflect national policy making and that participating in them takes away from the time a legislator could otherwise devote to local benefit-seeking.
This is indeed what the House's data indicate, particularly in the case of this institution.
The attendance rate of the Democratic House has not surpassed that of the Republican House since 1959.

Finally, as the table indicates, Democrats assign a higher proportion of their personal staffs to district offices -- where local benefit-seeking duties are more significant and national policy-making activities are less so, compared to those in Washington offices.

An examination of changes in personal staffing decisions in the Senate between 1986 and 1987 -LRB- when control of the Senate changed party hands -RRB- , moreover , reveals that the staffing differences noted in the table cannot be attributed to the disproportionate control the Democrats exercise , due to their majority-party status , over other resources such as committee staff .

An additional piece of evidence from the Senate shows that, when holding factors such as incumbency advantages and regional differences constant, the discrepancy in popular votes for Republican presidential versus senatorial candidates in states hosting a Senate election is positively correlated with the onerousness of the federal government's tax burden per state -LRB- a progressive tax rate affects higher-income states more severely -RRB-.
Put more simply, voters look on GOP candidates for president more kindly than they do on Republican candidates for the Senate when that prisoner's dilemma is more severe.
Moreover, the same peculiar pattern of ticket splitting that appears at the state government level also seems to take place at the federal level.
Republican governors and Democratic legislatures are more typically found in split state governments than the other way around.

A cross-state econometric investigation, furthermore, reveals that, holding other factors constant, the difference between the vote for the Republican gubernatorial candidate in a state and the Republicans' share of the lower state house is a positive function of the state tax rate.
In sum, at least part of the seemingly irrational behavior that voters display in the voting booth at both federal and state government levels may have an exceedingly rational explanation.

The nine-day Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta, which is held annually in the U.S., includes the largest gathering of ersatz Phineas Fogg. It attracts around 800,000 enthusiasts and over 500 balloons, with some shaped to look like Carmen Miranda, Garfield, or a 12-story-high condom.
This year, the official entry status was denied to the condom balloon.
But in that gray 16th-century river town adjacent to France's Vosges mountain region, none of the Yankee-come-lately enthusiasms for things aloft was evident in Epinal.
Ballooning at the de rigueur hour of 6 a.m. held all the attraction for them, the people of sunrise root-canal work.
Feeling the naggings that a culture imperative imposed, I promptly signed up.
The first thing anybody will tell you about ballooning is that this activity requires zip in the way of athletic prowess, or even a measure of derring-do.
So long as it is not me looking down.
They will also tell you that even if you hate heights, you can still go in this balloon.
I still say you should not look down.
At least not when one is ascending.
What people won't tell you is not to go aloft in anything that you don't want to get wet.
I'm not referring to that traditional champagne drenching during the back-on-terra-firma toast.
I'm talking about it landing in a canal.
In that porous wicker basket.
The pilot speaks no English.
To wit, the start of my maiden voyage and the novitiates, referred to as virgins, commenced at dawn on a dew-sodden fairway and concluded at noon in a soggy field.
Balloon flights almost always occur at this time of day, which is at dawn or dusk, when the winds are lightest.

In between, there was a lot of coffee drinking while watching these balloons inflate, and plenty of standing around deciding who would fly in which balloon and in what order the baskets, each holding no more than four passengers, would be used.
When it wasn't my turn in the balloon, I followed the balloon's progress from the chase car, listening to the driver holler into a walkie-talkie.
After long stretches of the attendant ground activity came 20 or so lovely minutes of drifting above these mountains, watching the silver mists rise off the river and the cows amble about the fields.
It's hard not to feel that God is in His heaven with a view like this, even if your pilote in the silly plaid beret kept pointing out how 'belle' everything was.
Eventually the little French farmers and their wives emerged from their stone houses, put their hands above their small eyes, and squinted at us.
We were coming down straight into that canal of theirs.
You ca n't steer, see, that's another rule of thumb about ballooning.
And neither can he.
You can go only up or down by heating the balloon's air with this propane burner, which does make the top of your head feel hot and ride these air currents.
The chase car makes that necessary.
Balloonists seldom ascend beyond 2,000 feet, and they typically average a leisurely 5-10 miles per hour.
When it is cruising along at a steady altitude, the balloon gives little sense of motion.
Only when you are descending -- or in our case, going down a bit too quickly -- do you feel, well, as if you're airborne in a picnic basket.
What's that person doing?' hissed my companion, the only other English-speaking member of the convention, whose knuckles had turned white.
Attention, yelled the pilot as that basket plunged into the canal.
You bet attention, I yelled back to him, leaping atop these propane tanks, I'm wearing alligator loafers!
Our pilot simply laughed, fired up the burner, and with another blast of flame, lifted these, oh, a good 12-inches above the water level.
He scuttled us along for a few feet before plunging us into the drink again.

Eventually we came to rest in that soggy patch of field where we had the exquisite pleasure of scrambling out of the basket into the mud while they, the French half of our ballooning tag team, scrambled in.
I looked at this watch.
It was barely half-an-hour in the air.
Back in the chase car, we drove around some more, got stuck in a ditch, enlisted the aid of a local farmer to get the trailer hitch out and pull us from the ditch.

We finally rendezvoused with our balloon, which, as the Epinalers watched, had come to rest on a dirt road. They observed our half-an-hour of non-flight activity, which included the precision routine of yanking it to the ground, punching all the air out, rolling it up, and cramming it and the basket into the trailer.
The most exercise we'd had all morning was this, and it was followed by our immediately driving to the nearest watering hole.
This meant going back to the golf course, where we saw a few French duffers attack the first tee as we sat under the Cinzano umbrellas, I nursing an espresso and my ego.
I had been off the ground for barely 30 minutes after a whole morning of ballooning.
Still, I figured that back in the U.S.A., the envy-quotient of the event was nearly peerless.
As for the ride back to camp, our pilot and all the others clambered into that chase car.
My companion and I were left to ride alfresco in the wicker basket.
As we streaked by the gendarme, I couldn't resist rearing up on my soggy loafers and saluting him.
A free-lance writer, that is Ms. de Vries.
The U.N. group has drafted a plan to reduce these emissions

The conference sponsored by the U.N. -- marked by unruly posturing and mutual recriminations -- regained focus on Friday with the release of a document detailing ambitious greenhouse-gas reductions for the following 40 years, with they, the industrialized nations, bearing most of the burden in the short term.
The text, which could provide this basis for a final political deal to regulate greenhouse gases, highlighted these remaining obstacles as much as it illuminated the path forward.
But the negotiation was seen as an important advance that is running out of time, with more than 100 world leaders arriving in Copenhagen next week.
The text, forged by a U.N. ad-hoc working group, does not specify the amount of money that rich countries would provide to poor ones for dealing with global warming in both the short and long term.

And these provide a range of options for the key questions, including how developed and major emerging economies would cut their carbon output, and what the upper limit of global temperature rise policymakers would be willing to tolerate.
John Coequyt, the senior Washington representative for the Sierra Club, said that it gives a lot of flexibility to the process.
Michael Zammit Cutajar, who drafted the document, reduced a 180-page negotiation text to concentrate on what Yvo de Boer, the U.N.'s top climate official, referred to as 'this big picture'.

The outlines for a possible deal show that industrial nations would collectively cut their emissions by 2020 by 25 to 45 percent compared with 1990 levels, whereas major developing countries would reduce these during the same period by 15 to 30 percent.
Together, they would cut emissions between 50 and 95 percent by 2050.

The European Union also boosted the talks on Friday by pledging to give $3.6 billion annually over the following three years to assist these poorer countries in adapting to the effects of climate change, ranging from dealing with floods and droughts to preventing deforestation.
Still, the same sort of verbal fireworks that have dominated the talks for the past week were featured on Friday.

U.S. special climate envoy Todd Stern rejected language that required binding cuts of greenhouse-gas emissions for industrialized countries like ours compared with voluntary ones by major emerging economies if they were not funded by the developed world.
The Obama administration's move signaled it is taking a harder line with China than those Bush administration officials did just two years ago.

Stern said the United States would not engage in a deal unless the major developing countries, which he complained had not taken sufficient action, ensured the text was robust enough for the cuts to be verified by external observers.

An hour after the Chinese vice foreign minister He Yafei spoke, Stern made his comments, stating that America's top climate negotiator had either shown a lack of common sense or been extremely irresponsible by claiming earlier in the week that the United States would not provide financial assistance to China in dealing with global warming.

With the future economic trajectory of major powers like the United States at stake, fault lines have erupted both within the developing world and between the industrial world and economies such as China's.

The ongoing struggle is as much about rescuing specific economies as it is about preserving this planet, with China and the United States disputing over their obligations while those poorer nations maintain that the world's two dozen most powerful countries are neglecting the scientific imperative for more aggressive action.

Ricardo Ulate, a Costa Rican delegate, stated that it's not surprising these major powers are disputing who will assume the costs of curbing greenhouse gases, while those vulnerable countries have been more proactive in making the big emitters responsible for their actions.
Ulate, the regional Mexico and Central America climate change adviser for Conservation International, said that this is clearly a game where a new economic hegemony is being developed.

Most of the major participants say the talks in Copenhagen will produce a political deal at best, although some of the countries most vulnerable to climate change, such as those indicated, would continue to push for a legally binding treaty.
The group of 43 members, known as the Alliance of Small Island States, drafted a 24-page treaty proposal early Friday morning.

Artur Runge-Metzger, who leads on behalf of the European Commission in international climate negotiations, noted that the unified push by small island nations has `` exerted political pressure on the whole political process, `` partly because these nations are now demanding action from emerging economies like China and India.
The delegates focused on the fact that most of the outstanding issues must be resolved before the heads of government, such as they, arrive to strike a deal, thus infusing the talks with new urgency.

High-level officials including Jairam Ramesh, the Indian environment minister, and that Chinese vice minister stepped off the planes and hurried through the Bella Center's halls to closed-door meetings and news conferences, so that they could establish claims which will be arbitrated during the following week.

The gathering -- where 13,000 individuals move in and out of the convention center daily, guitar-playing activists mock these countries they believe are selling out during nightly shows, and they pass draft proposals by hand on paper instead of using email -- presents a challenge.
Nearly all of the key ministers, including those who are most critical, are now here; and by Wednesday, 60 heads of government, including those from Copenhagen, will have arrived.
Carlos Manuel Rodriguez, vice president for global policy at Conservation International, said that they were getting into the big leagues.
They are coming, the heavyweights.

The Cheshire Appeal will direct attention to Twitter.
There were half a dozen people typing away in the rows of the courtroom.
Minute by minute, Twitter relayed their reports of gruesome testimony.
In the end, the defense claims there were more than 140,000 Twitter messages concerning the trial, which addressed the rape of children who were tied to their beds in that house that was set on fire.

On Thursday, the widely followed trial of Steven J. Hayes, who was convicted of killing these three members of a Cheshire, Conn., family, is set to come to an official end with that judge's imposition of the death sentence voted for by the jury.
But Mr. Hayes' lawyers have already filed documents with the court that outline appeal arguments likely to engage the courts for years.

The intense reporting on the trial - including the extensive use of Twitter by mainstream reporters - created a 'circus atmosphere' and such widespread, instant saturation with inflammatory details that public passions improperly swayed the jury.
The question of whether new technology requires new courtroom rules could force these appeals judges to grapple with it.

As Thomas J. Ullmann, Mr. Hayes's chief defense lawyer, experienced it during this trial, he thinks there's a real danger that the inclusion of new technology in the courtroom is affecting individuals' fair-trial rights.

Jon C. Blue, the trial judge of State Superior Court, tersely dismissed the claims in a ruling last week, stating that the media had been “carefully controlled`` and that there was no indication that they had been influenced by passion.
But it is not likely to be the last word on this issue.
For decades, these appeals courts have recognized that the coverage of those notorious cases can raise questions about fairness in a trial.

In a landmark 1966 ruling, the United States Supreme Court overturned Dr. Sam Sheppard's conviction for the murder of his wife, stating in the decision of Sheppard v. Maxwell that there was a 'carnival atmosphere at trial' due to the news media.
Some believe the television show and `` The Fugitive `` movie were inspired by this crime.

Some lawyers suggested that appeals courts, when reviewing the conviction of Mr. Hayes a half-century later, might find the argument intriguing that new rules could be essential to regulate communication methods in courtrooms that were inconceivable during Dr. Sheppard's case.

John J. Donohue III, a Stanford Law School professor, expressed concern about the impact of new media in high-profile trials, noting there is a general reason for worry. He studied the Connecticut death penalty and authored a report indicating it was enforced arbitrarily.
Professor Donohue suggested that the idea of limiting instant communication from courtrooms might intrigue some judges, potentially leading to fairer trials.
Mr. Hayes's lawyers have outlined many issues, including this one with Twitter, which are likely to be argued for years, thus delaying an execution.

The defense lawyers also claim, for example, that Mr. Hayes may have been prejudiced when Judge Blue declined to allow the potential jurors to test their reactions by viewing the grisly crime-scene photographs during jury selection.
Some of the jurors have said they were horrified by these photographs of the victims, including Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her children, Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11.

The defense lawyers say they will also challenge the constitutionality of the death penalty and argue that the judge wrongly removed this critical juror and that he improperly added pressure for a verdict with this unusual decision to direct the jury to deliberate over a weekend.
They were not sequestered, the jurors.
But the arguments about the effect of the intense coverage of this trial may draw the most interest.

The challenge to the verdict, filed in the previous month, dominated the news in Connecticut and was a topic of discussion among candidates for governor and the United States Senate during the election campaign.
The news media continually fanned the flames of emotion about this case, as they argued.
The lawyers wrote that the daily crush of media tweets, cameras, and reporters outside New Haven Courthouse was unlike anything ever seen there or perhaps statewide.
The focus on Twitter's coverage is controversial.

In interviews, some journalists claimed that this instantaneous news was more incendiary than those reports delivered more slowly, a Luddite perspective that would make for poor court policy in governing the coverage of future trials.
But some lawyers said these courts were often attracted to arguments that such social and technological changes required their adaptation.
That claim is being pressed by Mr. Hayes's lawyers.

In their filing, they referred to the 1966 decision of the Supreme Court that overturned Dr. Sheppard's conviction due to the trial coverage, making it clear that they would argue that these new media necessitated new rules.
The case, they wrote, represents the Sheppard v. Maxwell of this century.
Sport and that law regarding fraud
Tricks such as Alonso's and Ramos's before the Ajax match demonstrate wittiness but not the will to remove a sanction.

The expulsion presumably forged by Xabi Alonso and Sergio Ramos, two players of Real Madrid, in the game against Ajax on the 23rd of November in the European Champions League has caused rivers of ink to be written about whether their behavior is unsportsmanlike and if they should be sanctioned by UEFA.
As we all know, a few minutes before the end of the game (which their team had already won), the players deliberately wasted time, which led the referee to show the second yellow card to them.

This way, since Real Madrid will finish as the group's leader, they will fulfil the prescribed sanction during the next league game against Auxerre, and will be able to get rid of those cards in the following phase.
Finally, the UEFA's disciplinary committee has sanctioned Jose Mourinho, the team's trainer, with two games, and the players involved with varying economic amounts.
The provocation leading to a yellow card in circumstances similar to those is not a new practice, but rather a frequent occurrence in the football world.
This sport is so extended that it becomes part of the ethos and the unwritten rules, which are followed nonetheless.

Part of the debate arising in the related case is caused by the fact that the team of Real Madrid, an organization that in its hymn boasts of nobility and honor, has fined its players for similar acts, and by the dramatization apparently orchestrated by Mourinho, who adds to his extensive history as a histrionic and provoking technician.

Anyway, the debate revolves around whether behavior not explicitly prohibited by the regulation, such as these actions, contradicts the principles of the sport. In other words, if it constitutes fraud, then they are actions that respect the sport's regulation, but they appear to evade its spirit.
The type of damage examines the impact it has on the sporting spirit.
One of the advantages that include the spirit of sport is the integrity of the players on the other team, an aspect that these actions didn't put in danger, meaning there was no violent game.
Another of these advantages, alluded to with fare-play, is to avoid the team of lawbreaker players taking advantage of the opposing team, which did not occur.

However, the paradoxical thing about Real Madrid's players' action is that it did not conform to what we generally consider legal fraud; the violation of rules was not committed secretly to evade sanctions, but their actions were most apparent, leading to punishment from the referee.
The team waited for and accepted that sanction without any complaints.
Another question is what type of advantage they obtained in the actions these violators deliberately carried out.

Here it seems necessary to state that this isn't a disadvantageous situation for rivals nor is a benefit obtained in the same game, because evidently the result of the action supposes leaving their team with fewer players.
And neither is that a useful strategy for the next game, because the club will not be able to count on them.
The fact that the players will start the next phase of the Championship without cards that could jeopardize their involvement in a future game is the obvious advantage.

But this is about a long-term advantage, with a certain degree of indetermination, because the team can be eliminated first in a change, and in addition, they fulfill a sanction game with this action, proceeding to the second cycle of cards, where the suspension due to card accumulation occurs less frequently than in the first cycle.
So that, by passing these rounds, it is not so clear that this is an advantage.
Actions that are against the sporting spirit, which is a part of strategic decisions, favor taking the advantages these rules allow.
Regarding the assumption, the players did not act to avoid the application of the sanction, which would have been a clear case of legal fraud, but rather chose when to obey that.
A strategic decision was made by them without avoiding the punishment.
Although the border between the wittiness and the law fraud is diffuse, on this occasion I believe the distinction was a clear case of wittiness.
The controversy seems to arise from these two factors: the auto expulsions and how the transmission of that directive was carried out, which caused them.
The damage these actions bring to the principles of sport is not as much about ethics as it is about aesthetics.
The possibility of new types of life on Earth, or elsewhere, is raised by the arsenic-tolerant microbe.
A strange bacteria, which can use arsenic as one of its nutrients, has expanded the scope for discovering new forms of life on Earth and perhaps elsewhere.

While the researchers discovered this unusual bacteria on our planet, they say this discovery suggests that life could exist with possibilities beyond those major elements previously considered essential.
This organism possesses dual abilities.
It can grow with this element, either phosphorus or arsenic.

Paul C. W. Davies of Arizona State University, a co-author of the report in Thursday's online edition of the journal Science, commented, 'This makes it very peculiar, though it falls short of being some form of truly `alien' life.'
Life has long been considered to depend on six essential elements: carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, phosphorus, and sulfur.
The researchers discovered that this bacteria, found in Mono Lake, Calif., can continue to grow by substituting arsenic for phosphorus.
Ariel D. Anbar, a co-author of the report from Arizona State University, said, 'It makes you wonder what else is possible.'
Anbar explained that the discovery is crucial for the search for extraterrestrial life, as the researchers must be capable of identifying it and understanding what it appears to be.
The study focuses on this microbe found on our planet.

However, the news conference announcement to discuss the report, which did not disclose these details, generated widespread speculation on the Internet that it would reveal the discovery of extraterrestrial life.
That did not happen.

Charles Cockell, professor at the Planetary and Space Sciences Research Institute, Open University, in Milton Keynes, United Kingdom, commented that the discovery does show that these other planetary environments could potentially allow organisms to utilize different elements for biochemistry, indicating that the set of elements we consider essential for life may not be as fixed as we believe.
The research team did not include Cockell.
Cockell added that this work is novel because it demonstrates the substitution of one element for another in fundamental biochemistry and biochemical structure.
That was not a chance discovery.
Felisa Wolfe-Simon of NASA's Astrobiology Institute, who led the study, targeted Mono Lake because that has high arsenic levels.
She speculated that a microbe exposed to both arsenic and phosphorus might be able to substitute this for that.
Arsenic is toxic mainly because its chemical behavior is so similar to phosphorus's.
As a result, these organisms have a hard time distinguishing between the elements.
But arsenic is different enough that it does n't work as well as phosphorus does, so it gets in there and sort of gums up the works of our biochemical machinery, explained Anbar.
The researchers collected the bacteria known as GFAJ-1 and exposed them to increasing concentrations of arsenic, which they were able to adapt to and grow in.

The microbe does grow better on phosphorus, but demonstrating this adaptability to arsenic raises the possibility that life forms using arsenic could exist naturally, either elsewhere on this planet, or on another planet or moon where arsenic is more prevalent.

Jamie S. Foster, an assistant professor of microbiology at the University of Florida, said this idea that arsenic could be substituted for phosphorus isn't new, but there has never been an example where such a substitution was demonstrated to be effective.
She said that Arsenic was more common in the early times on Earth, so researchers have speculated that early life forms might have used that.
Foster, who was not part of Wolfe-Simon's team, suggested there could be other ways to form life, not just how life formed on Earth in its early stages.
NASA, the Department of Energy, and the National Institutes of Health supported this research.
This democratic routine
As support for democracy in Latin America continues to edge up, so does that for private enterprise.
Unemployment is less of a worry than Crime has become.
And the United States is considered less influential than Brazil across much of the region.
The latest Latinobarómetro poll, taken in 18 countries, includes some of these findings, which were published exclusively by The Economist.
Because the poll taken regularly since 1995 tracks these changes in attitude across the region.
The results of the poll conducted in September and early October highlight two related factors this year.
Latin America has a fairly sunny mood as its first characteristic.
The increasing stability of attitudes towards democracy and these core institutions is the second.
Support for democracy in these countries on the Pacific rim of South America has risen noticeably.

For example, in Peru, where economic growth has averaged 6% a year since 2002, support for democracy has risen from a low of 40% in 2005 to 61% this year, showing a significant increase from that low point.
Mexico also saw a rise, where the economy has recovered after suffering a big drop in output last year.
But only around half of the respondents in these two most populous countries of the region, Mexico and Brazil, are convinced democrats, which drags down the regional average (see chart 2).

Some 44% of those polled in the region declared they were content with the functioning of their democracy in practice, matching the previous year's figure and showing a significant rise from the 25% in 2001 (chart 3).
Some 34% said they had confidence in Congress and 45% in the government, the same as it was last year in both cases but up sharply from 2003 (17% and 24% respectively).
A decade ago, the economic woes in this region undermined the support for democracy.
The fact that the world financial crisis has held up is probably because many Latin American countries suffered only a brief recession and have enjoyed a strong recovery.
In addition, the poor have been shielded by a stronger social safety net.

The Economic Commission for Latin America of the United Nations reported this week that the proportion of those living in poverty in Latin America rose only marginally in 2009 and has fallen again this year, to 32%.
But the mood in each country varies widely (see chart 4).
The strong economic performance of Brazil and the popularity of its outgoing president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, reflect a widely shared sense of progress.
The scarcity is more pronounced in Mexico and Central America, regions where the recession was more severe and violent crime has intensified.

The healthcare law challengers dined with Scalia and Thomas as the court took the case.

The day the Supreme Court assembled in private to deliberate on the politically charged question of whether they would take up a challenge to President Obama's healthcare law, two of the justices, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, were honored at a dinner hosted by the law firm that is set to argue the case before the high court.
Last Thursday was the occasion, when the nine justices gathered for a conference to pour over the review petitions.

A suit brought by 26 states, which was one of the cases at issue, challenged the sweeping healthcare overhaul passed by Congress the previous year; this law has been a rallying cry for conservative activists across the country.

Indeed, a landmark 5.5-hour argument is expected in March, and the outcome is likely to further roil the 2012 presidential race, which will be in full swing by the time the court's decision regarding this suit is released, as the justices have agreed to hear it.

Paul Clement, the lawyer who will stand before the court and argue that the law should be thrown out, is likely to be the one who served as U.S. solicitor general during the George W. Bush administration.

Bancroft PLLC, Clement's law firm, was one of nearly two dozen firms that contributed to sponsoring the annual dinner of the Federalist Society, a long-standing group committed to promoting conservative legal principles.
Jones Day, the firm that sponsored the dinner, represents the National Federation of Independent Business, one of the trade associations that challenged the law.
Pfizer Inc, the pharmaceutical giant, had an enormous financial stake in the outcome of the litigation, as did another sponsor.
A Washington hotel hosted the dinner hours after the court's conference about that case concluded.
Among those in attendance was Mitch McConnell, the Senate's top Republican, who is an avowed opponent of the healthcare law.
Scalia and Thomas were the featured guests at the dinner.
It's nothing new: The Federalist Society has been hosting events for these two justices over the years.
And nothing runs afoul of the ethics rules it establishes.
In fact, the Code of Conduct that governs the actions of lower federal justices does not apply to them.

If those judges did, they arguably fell under Canon 4C's code, which states, ``A judge may attend fund-raising events of law-related and other organizations although the judge may not be a speaker, a guest of honor, or featured on the program of such an event.``

Nevertheless, the close association of Scalia and Thomas with those two law firms in the case, along with their ties to the company that held a substantial financial interest, was sufficient to concern government ethics activists.

This shocking breach of ethics and disregard for the code contradicts the claims of several justices, who say the court follows the same rules as all other federal judges, said Bob Edgar, the president of Common Cause.
The attorneys, who have pending cases before the court, were wining and dining with the justices at a black-tie fundraiser.
The appearance and help of them in fundraising for this event undercuts any claims of impartiality, and is unacceptable.
Scalia and Thomas have shown little regard for the critics who say these justices too readily mix the business of the court with agenda-driven groups, such as the Federalist Society.
And Ginni, Thomas's wife, is a high-profile conservative activist.
Moreover, conservatives argue that Justice Elena Kagan has an ethical issue, not Scalia and Thomas.
In the Obama administration, Kagan, as the solicitor general, faced the initial legal challenges to that law at the trial court level.
Critics have pushed for Kagan to recuse herself from hearing this case, saying that Kagan was too invested in defending that law then to be impartial now.
She has given no indication that Kagan will do so.

Is the economy burdened or enhanced by immigration?

Nicolas Sarkozy's immigration policy was criticised on various fronts, including a congestion of police, legal, and administrative services, which were subject to a policy driven by numbers and its compatibility with the country's self-proclaimed status as the protector of French human rights.

More recently, the administrative harassment of foreign students has been a topical issue, with the minister of the interior, as reported by 'Libération' on 23 May, declaring that France does not need them—foreign talent, bricklayers, and waiters.
But the economic viewpoint is only rarely analyzed.
There is a lot of consensus between the Left and those on the Right regarding this subject.

Jacques Chirac set the tone on the Right in 1976, declaring that '900,000 unemployed would not become a problem in a country with 2 million of these foreign workers,' and Michel Rocard did so on the Left in 1990, explaining that France 'cannot accommodate all that the world's misery has to offer.'
The degree of generosity is the only difference
In 2005, the national territory's fear of being invaded by hordes of Polish plumbers was a concern for both the Left and the Right sides of the political spectrum.
Both sides consider them a burden on the French economy and French society.
The difference lies solely in the level of generosity that people deign to grant to these immigrants.
In François Hollande's program, he confines himself to banalities, saying that co-development would solve that immigration problem.
The idea that immigration is a burden and a problem may be an electoral asset, but it is economically very costly.

In their recent book summarizing the most current knowledge of immigration, Ian Goldin and Geoffrey Cameron, the economists, remind us that there is a wide consensus among specialists regarding the positive impact of migration flows on economic growth, wages, and employment in countries that receive immigrants.
Restraining this immigration policy leads to anaemic economic growth and harms employment levels.
The notion that immigrants are likely to replace native workers, especially unskilled ones like them, leads to fears of downward pressure on wages.
Experience demonstrates that in reality, they are much more complementary to local labor, rather than replacements for it, in trades where there is a shortage of this labor.
Unskilled immigrants work in these sectors, which do not attract local labor and those most highly skilled ones in dynamic sectors where training is not linked to employment offers.
Wages have a positive effect

In the same way that a surgeon would struggle to operate in a country facing a shortage of anaesthetists, the synergies between the local population and immigrants result in the positive impact that their arrival has on the local wages.
Giovanni Peri's calculations indicate that when the migratory flow increases by 1%, there is a corresponding rise of between 0.6 and 0.9% in real long-term pay.

And it does so without considering the fact that the diversity immigrants bring contributes to the creation of ideas and economic growth; a large proportion of naturalized immigrants are among the American Nobel Prize winners, and companies like Google, Intel, Paypal, eBay, and Yahoo were founded by them.
They are also net contributors to social systems, averaging 1% of the total budgets of European countries.

The World Labor Organisation estimates that, for instance, when an immigrant arrives in Germany at 30 years of age, they will make a net contribution (receipts minus expenditure) of an average 150,000 Euros to public budgets over their lifetime.
At the start of his mandate, Nicolas Sarkozy wished to seek `` with the teeth `` the missing points of growth that were needed.
These teeth, intended to serve as a deterrent to immigrants, had precisely the opposite effect.

Alimta is a medication used for the treatment of lung cancer and mesothelioma.
A solution made from Alimta powder is used for infusion, which is dripped into a vein.
Pemetrexed is the active substance it contains.
Alimta is used for what?
Two types of cancer, including pleural mesothelioma, which is cancer of this lining of the lungs usually caused by exposure to asbestos, are treated with Alimta.

When the cancer that patients have is unresectable and malignant, Alimta, along with cisplatin, is the treatment used; this occurs in cases where the non-small cell lung cancer has not affected the squamous cells and the patients have not undergone previous chemotherapy.
Patients who have not been treated before often receive a combination of Alimta and cisplatin, while those who have received another type of chemotherapy in the past may be treated with Alimta alone.
Only with a prescription can you obtain this medicine.
How do you use Alimta?
Only a doctor qualified in the use of anticancer chemotherapy should supervise the administration of Alimta.
The recommended dose for Alimta is 500 mg for each square metre of it (calculated using the patient's height and weight).
The intravenous infusion is given once every three weeks, lasting 10 minutes.

To minimize side effects, those undergoing treatment with Alimta should ingest corticosteroids and folic acid, which is a type of vitamin, as well as receive vitamin B12 injections during the process.
When given with cisplatin, an anti-emetic (to prevent vomiting) and fluids (to prevent dehydration) should also be administered before or after that dose of cisplatin.
In patients with abnormal blood counts or certain other side effects, treatment should be delayed or discontinued, or the dose should be reduced.
Patients with moderate or severe kidney problems should not use Alimta.
For more information, consult the section titled 'Product Characteristics' in the EPAR (which is also a part of it).
How does it work, Alimta?
Pemetrexed, the active substance in Alimta, is a cytotoxic medicine, which is part of the antimetabolites group and kills cells that are dividing, such as cancer cells.
In the body, pemetrexed is converted into its active form, which blocks the activity of enzymes involved in producing nucleotides, the building blocks of DNA and RNA, the cells' genetic material.
How have studies been conducted on Alimta?
For the treatment of their malignant pleural mesothelioma, 456 patients were studied in one main study who had not received chemotherapy before Alimta was administered.
The effects of Alimta combined with cisplatin were compared to the effects of cisplatin by itself.

In one study involving 571 patients with locally advanced or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer, the effects of Alimta were compared to those of docetaxel, another anticancer medicine, for the treatment they had received chemotherapy in the past.
A study involving 1,725 patients who had not received chemotherapy for lung cancer in the past compared Alimta with gemcitabine (another anticancer medicine), both in combination with cisplatin.
In all three studies, the primary indicator of effectiveness was the duration of survival for these patients.
What benefit has been shown by Alimta during the studies?
Patients with malignant pleural mesothelioma experienced increased survival time due to Alimta.
Patients receiving Alimta and cisplatin survived for an average of 12.1 months, compared with 9.3 months for those receiving only cisplatin.
In patients who had received chemotherapy in the past, the average survival time for those with Alimta was 8.3 months, compared to 7.9 months for those with docetaxel.
In those who had not received chemotherapy previously, the average survival time for the patients was 10.3 months in each group.
However, in both studies, patients with cancer not affecting squamous cells had longer survival times if they received Alimta than when given that comparator.
In contrast, patients with squamous cell cancer had shorter survival times if Alimta was received by them.
